Rob, I believe your topology is correct and should be able to solve 
XOR.

=
One thing you might want to do as a sanity check is find a solution 
to XOR=
 in a neural network textbook and plug it into your system and 
run your ne=
twork activation function it.  Or even better, run my 
version of NEAT to c=
reate an XOR solution and then load that into 
your system and test it.

Th=
en I would check into the weight mutations.  I would try very 
different un=
iform distribution sizes to see if one of them works.  
It's possible your =
weight mutations are for some reason too big or 
too small.

However, first=
 let me know if your networks activate correctly on 
solutions that you kno=
w should work.  

ken


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Rob" <auto_phile@...>=
 wrote:
>
> Yet another "I can't get XOR to work" post :(
> 
> I'm trying t=
o implement a NEAT package in ECJ. To test it, I'm 
running
> XOR with fixe=
d topology, but my runs only seem to train to three of
> the four fitness c=
ases. Let me describe what I'm doing, and maybe
> someone can spot a flaw? =
I can also send the source code to anyone
> that asks -- you just need ECJ.=

> 
> There are three input nodes (0, 1, 2). The first two are the inputs
>=
 (taking values of 0.0 or 1.0) and the third is a fixed bias node
> (always=
 of value 1.0).
> 
> The output node is 3, and the hidden node is 4. The co=
nnections are 
as
> follows:
> 
> (0, 1, 2) -> (3, 4)
> 4 -> 3
> 
> which m=
akes 7 connections in all. The activation function of each 
node
> is 1/(1+=
exp(-4.9*x)).
> 
> The fitness function is defined as the sum of 1.0 - abs(=
target -
> output), which means that the worst individuals have a fitness o=
f 0
> and the best have a fitness of 4.
> 
> I initialize the population wi=
th N networks. The weights in each
> network are uniformly distributed as [=
-5,+5). Initially, all 
networks
> are in one species.
> 
> Since individua=
ls do not differ in topology, they always have the 
same
> number of genes,=
 so the delta between individuals is calculated as
> M*W/7, where M is the =
matching factor, W is the absolute difference 
in
> weights, and 7 is the n=
umber of matching genes. I'm using M =3D 2.0 
for
> my runs, since that see=
ms to keep around 3 species.
> 
> Each generation, the individuals in each =
species are evaluated, and
> ordered from fitness best to worst. The best i=
ndividual in each
> species is copied into the next generation. The overall=
 fitness of
> each species is also computed taking the average fitness of t=
he
> individuals in that species.
> 
> Each species is then assigned a numb=
er of new individuals to create,
> which is proportional to the species fit=
ness.
> 
> To create a new individual, I take one parent from the top 40% o=
f 
the
> species, and another parent randomly from the species (or with 0.1=
%
> probability an elite from a different species). I cross the parents,
> =
which involves randomly selecting each gene from each parent.
> 
> Then, wi=
th probability 50%, I mutate the weights of the result: With
> 90% probabil=
ity, each weight is perturbed by a gaussian of standard
> deviation 2.0, an=
d capped to +/- 5.0. Otherwise (10% probability) 
the
> weights are uniform=
ly selected from [-5, +5).
> 
> Once the individuals are created, each indi=
vidual is compared with 
one
> representative from the previous species. If=
 the individual matches 
to
> within 2.0, the individual is assigned to tha=
t species. Otherwise, a
> new species is created, with that individual beco=
ming the
> representative for that species. On a typical run, the number of=

> species bounces between 2 and 3, with occasional excursions to 4.
> 
> T=
hat's about it. I end up with individuals that satisfy three of the
> four =
cases. Can any one spot an obvious flaw? Parameters that are
> obviously wr=
ong? Any help would be greatly appreciated.
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> --Rob
>
